name: Thirumalirunjolai
thirukkolam: Standing posture along with Sridevi, Bhoodevi, and the five weapons (Panchayudha) including the Prayoga Chakra.
theertham: Noopura Gangai, also known as Silambaru.
festival: Chithirai Pournami Festivalâ€”the festival where the Lord departs for Madurai to witness the wedding of his sister, Meenakshi.
note: There is a belief that every night at midnight, Lord Yama (God of Death) visits this shrine to worship Lord Alagar.

name: Srivilliputhur
thirukkolam: Vatapatra Sayanam (Reclining on a banyan leaf)
mangalasasanam: Both Periyazhwar and Sri Andal; 2 Pasurams (hymns)
festival: Throughout the month of Margazhi, the thirty Thiruppavai hymns composed by Sri Andal are recited along with lullabies. In the month of Aadi, the Pooram star (the birth star of Andal) is celebrated grandly. The Brahmotsavam is held very grandly. On the 5th day, the Five Perumals appear in the Garuda Seva, and on the 9th day, the Chariot Festival (Ther) takes place.
note: The temple tower (Gopuram) is 164 feet high and is the official emblem of the Tamil Nadu government. The idol of Lakshmi Narayanan, worshipped by Periyazhwar during his lifetime, is kept and worshipped in a separate shrine today.

name: Thirukkoodal
theertham: Chakra Theertham, Krithamala River, Vaigai River
festival: Garuda Seva on the full moon day of the month of Aani, Sayana festival, and Mukkani (three fruits) festival. Ennai Kappu festival. The Periyazhwar festival takes place for ten days during the Swathi star in the month of Aani. The Navaratri festival in the month of Purattasi is celebrated grandly.
note: Among 96 types of Vimanams, the first and most magnificent is the Ashtanga Vimanam. Koodalazhagar is the Lord who gives darsan (Sevai) across the four Yugas. This is the place where Periyazhwar sang the "Thirupallandu" (sacred hymn).
